name: 🟠 Search
htmlBanner:
Search

Search offers users a way to explore a website or application using keywords. Search can be used as the primary means of discovering content or as a filter to aid the user in finding content.

Accessibility.html:
Overview

Accessibility for search input involves designing the text field in a way that makes it easy to use and understandable for people with disabilities. This includes providing clear and concise labels for the search text field, ensuring the field has enough contrast with the background, making it keyboard accessible, and providing clear focus indicators.
Additionally, designers should consider providing additional features to aid in search input, such as autocomplete suggestions, search filters, and search result refinement options. These features can help users find the information they need more easily.

Keyboard Navigation

To navigate a search field, use a Tab stop to navigate between elements.
Keyboard interactions for search fields include:

Search input with filter

Screen Reader

The search field screen reader must inform a user of at least the following, normally in this order:

Name - visible label OR screen reader text
Role - edit
State - required, read-only, disabled, etc.
Current value or changes in value

Screen readers may not read placeholder text. Screen reader output can vary significantly depending on the user’s web browser and other factors, so to accommodate screen reader users, you should always include a static label.

The following are the announcement orders:

Search, empty

Initial status not applicable

Search, empty with filter chip

Initial status not applicable

Search, typed

Initial status not applicable

Search, typed with filter chip

Initial status not applicable

Clear value button

Initial status not applicable

Global search

Annotated visual example of the Global Search Field

Contextual search

Annotated visual example of the Contextual Search Field

Layout

Global Default search field sizing

conceptual Default search field sizing

Spacing

Spacing with dropdown menu

When a dropdown menu appears during search typing, there should be 8px of spacing between the global search field and the dropdown menu.

Spacing within a global header

A search field may appear in a global header with other supportive action buttons.

Alignment in global header bar

When using a text text field as a search, the search will exist in a global header bar. When in this context, the search field should be middle aligned within the global header.

Conceptual search spacing

Spacing with dropdown menu

When a dropdown menu appears during search typing, there should be 8px of spacing between the global search field and the dropdown menu.

Tokens

Color and type tokens listed for component elements for each type and states. Color tokens can be found in the “Theme Tokens - Dark UI” library. Type tokens can be found in the “Tokens - Type Application” Library.

Guideline.html:
Anatomy

Global search bar used in the Webex App header

Use cases

When to use

To help users find data more efficiently within a complex or large data set. Use at a global level when searching an entire site. Use at a page level when searching through content on one page specifically. Use at a component level when searching data in a component, like a data table

When not to use

Do not use when there is small or limited amounts of data.
Do not use when the information is simple and can be found easily within one view.

Types

There are two styles of search, global and contextual. They share similar functionality but look visually different, influencing where to use them.

Style

Appearance

Use case

Global

A pill-shaped style with no outlines

Use when searching an entire site or app. Results can vary in type.

Contextual

A traditional input style with rounded corners

Use within a page or screen when searching through specific content. Results should be of a single type (i.e. users, devices, etc.)

Anatomy

Global

Container
Leading icon
Filter chip (optional)
Supporting text
Trailing icon (optional)

Contextual

Container
Label text (optional)
Leading icon
Supporting text
Trailing icon (optional)

Containers

The container holds all other component elements. The global search bar container has rounded corners and no stroke, while the contextual search field follows text field container specifications. See details here.

Global (top) and contextual (bottom) search containers.

Label Text

Label text informs users about what information is requested for a text field. Label text is optional for contextual search fields.

Label text should be aligned with the container, and always visible.

Label text shouldn't be truncated or take up multiple lines. Keep it short, clear, and fully visible.

DO use labels on contextual search fields when further context is needed.

DON’T use labels on global search fields where spacing is limited.

Icons

Leading icon

The left side of the bar should contain a non-functional search icon. The magnifying glass icon is a universal way to indicate search.

In instances where progress needs to be shown, the search icon can be replaced with a progress spinner icon.

Trailing icon

The right side of the bar should contain an optional clear button after text has been input.

Leading and trailing icon examples

Supporting text

Placeholder text

Placeholder text, or ‘hinted search text’ provides a short description of what the user will be able to search for.

Input text

Once the user starts typing, the placeholder text is replaced with the input text.

Hinted search text is replaced with input text

Behavior

Placement

The global search field is centered and usually at the top of the screen within an app header.

Contextual search bars are centered within the element they occupy, and most often span the width of the container.

On vertical scroll

Depending on needs, the app header that houses the global search field bar can scroll away with content or remain fixed at the top of the screen.

Responsive layout

When scaling layouts consider how the global search bar position and alignment should scale.

For most cases it is recommended that the global search bar maintains in its layout region and maintains a fixed width. Internal elements are anchored to the left and right as the parent container scales.

Mobile device specs coming soon.

Applying modifiers

Modifiers can be applied to a global search to further filter results.

Predefined queries, such as ‘in:’ ‘from:’ will populate as a chip in the global search bar.

Search results

Search uses an autocomplete behavior, meaning that the user doesn’t have to press Return to submit the search. Results are displayed in a Menu component as the user types. Present search results in a compact, organized list, grouping like items into similar sections.

Characters in list items matching input text are bolded for emphasis.

Consider including avatars or other high priority entities in search results that the user may want to access right away.

Search view after entering input text showing results

Empty states

Neither global search fields or contextual search fields have error states like other text fields. All errors or ‘null’ search queries should leverage empty states in place of search results.

Empty state examples in various results menus

Sizing

For all Search Field types, there is only one text field height size: 32px.

Content

Labels

Label text is not required and by default not shown in search fields. They should only be used on contextual search fields, but never global search fields where space is limited.
Keep labels short and concise. 4-5 words max.
Labels should clearly state the requirement status.
Don’t use a colon at the end of a label for a form field. The component already communicates the relationship between label and input.
Labels should typically be in noun form or a "thing" (like "Name" or "Password). But if an text field needs more of a call to action, it can use the action + verb construction.

Placeholder text

Placeholder text is required and by default is shown in search fields.
Placeholder text should describe what the user can search for (ie. Names, Emails, Groups, etc.)

Capitalization

Use sentence case for all main elements (Labels, Helper text, and Placeholder text), except for product names and proper nouns.

Errors (TBD)

Because search fields do not have an error state. All errors or ‘null’ search queries should leverage empty states in place of search results.

Empty states (TBD)

No errors; use empty states
